comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
From thegarrison link above -
" On 1 July 1899, the Royal Artillery was divided into three groups: the Royal Horse Artillery and Royal Field Artillery comprised one group, while the Coastal Defence, Mountain, Siege and Heavy artillery were split off into another group named the Royal Garrison Artillery. The third group continued to be titled simply Royal Artillery, and was responsible for ammunition storage and supply. The RFA and RHA both dressed as mounted soldiers, whereas the RGA dressed like foot soldiers. "

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The two pips on the cuffs would indicate that he was a First Lieutenant and not likely to have been just 17 - he was possibly as old as 18 or 19!  Beautiful portrait and he is a fine looking youngster, imagine all the thousands of similar young me who died in the war that came soon afterwards.  While it is still November it is a good time to remember them!

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: In the 1911 census Edward Francis Frazer is resident in Rockingham, Roscommon, aged 24 (so 17 in 1904), occupation Captain, Royal Field Reserve Artillery (As far as I can read it) born in China (so possibly the same chap as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] found in the 1901 census) living with his parents, 3 sisters and 2 servants.

comment._content: The Frazers with a z are in Rockingham in 1901, too, while young Edward Francis is at Aravon school in Bray.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Holy crap! The Frazers lived in Riversdale House a few miles outside Carrick-on-Shannon. This page about the house has this to say: He was an army doctor and he kept his medicine in alcoves under the stairs. The last of Dr Frazer's family are not long dead. Dr Frazer's daughter happened to meet her husband Captain C.J O Sullivan who was attached to the Connacht Rangers in Boyle in the early part of the Century at a garden party in Rockingham. She became the world famed screen actress, Maureen O Sullivan. Can it be true, is this young gentleman Maureen O'Sullivan's brother?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
No, but Uncle, maybe!

Full name, Maureen Paula O'Sullivan; born May 17, 1911, in Boyle, County Roscommon, Ireland; ... daughter of Charles Joseph and Mary Lovatt (Fraser) O'Sullivan;

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Remember that author I mentioned earlier, Edward Fraser? He co-wrote a large book about the Connaught Rangers.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: EFF's military record is here Too many abbreviations for me to make much sense of, but I'm sure there are people here who can decipher them. But I can see he spent most of WWi in Nigeria, and is listed as arriving at Liverpool from Lagos on the SS Abinsi in October 1916 (address given as Riversdale, Boyle, Co,. Roscommon) He resigned his commission in May 1920 and married in 2nd quarter of 1921

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: More on Maureen O'Sullivan: Her mother's family were Frazer's of Scottish background. With the onset of the 1914 - 1918 war her father was away for long periods so the Sullivan family moved to the maternal home at Riversdale Knockvicar Sad news for the family, Edward's brother John Irwin: Lt John Irwin Fraser of 2nd Battalion Connaught Rangers. John was born in China and was the son of the Surgeon General to the Royal Navy who lived at Riversdale House in Knockvicar. His sister married Capt Charles O’Sullivan then of the 4th Battalion and their child was Maureen O’Sullivan, the famous film actor. John died of wounds received in the defence of Soupir Farm on the River Aisne on the 14th September 1914 when the Rangers gave the Germans a bloody nose as they pushed them back from The Marne. On that day also Charles O’Sullivan, who was acting Lt Col of the 2nd Battalion was badly injured and took no further part in the fighting. John is buried at Vailley British Cemetery on the Aisne. He was 29 years old.

comment.author: 90613172@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]   He was born in Tientsin China 1886 where his father John Frazer of Riversdale Boyle Roscommon was working as a doctor.  The family subsequently moved back to Ireland around 1895.  He is the uncle of Maureen O'Sullivan the famous Irish actress

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] spelt with an "s" - that's why I couldn't find it!

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Looks like he was awarded the 1914-1915 Medal for service in WW1 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1914%E2%80%9315_Star He served in the Royal Field Artillery in Nigeria. I'll look again at his papers, see what else I can decipher. He also received a Nigeria 1918 clasp, for service in Africa, www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/30109882, although no picture... So he was likely involved in the capture of the two German colonies in Africa en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Africa_Campaign_%28World_War_I%29 The rest is showing what column he's listed in the official rolls... They probably still exist in some museum. You can access them here, by paying. www.militaryarchive.co.uk/the-rolls.html . The card shows the number of his roll, and in what column he's listed, easy enough to find him. He's in here somewhere too.... www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/catalogue/searchresults.asp?S... Carol, call your friends at the UK Archives, see if they can hook you up ;)

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Don't ask how I know all this stuff. We did it for Grampa when he was in WW1. Once you know where to look, the records all look the same. Don't pay for them either, usually your country's archives will have them available for free. Ancestry wanted 40 bucks for them, I said no thanks. Went to Archives Canada, poked around a bit and found them for free.

comment.author: 66941036@N05
comment._content: The helmet had originally had a spike at its top when adopted in 1878, but in 1902 the RFA and RGA adopted a ball top instead.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66941036@N05] I'm sure if I looked hard enough I'd find a 1902 editorial bemoaning the loss of the spike due to Health and Safety meddling.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
... not exactly, but a letter to The Times on June 28th 1902 had strong views on the new uniform, especially the helmet.:
MILITARY UNIFORM Sir, An an officer who has lived on his pay for some years, I venture to address you on the subject of the recent changes in officers' uniforms. [several lengthy paragraphs follow on gold lace (criticism of its removal), the tunic (mild criticism), mess kit (too plain), frock-coat (criticism - "savours or the Old Kent-road")] The new cap is good; but is nothing going to be done in the way of a new full-dree headdress for R.A., R.E., R.A.M.C., A.S.C., and line regiments? That most ugly of headdresses, the helmet, was introduced when we were intended to go to war in full dress as worn at home, and the only excuse for it is now gone. Taking into consideration the cost of the frock-coat, I estimate that the changes will increase, not reduce any expenses, and as a rule I shall not wear such a smart kit as formerly. [further complaints about the costs of the uniform] Yours faithfully, PAUPER
Full letter here

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Quite aside from which, with the advent of the machine gun and quick-firing artillery, cavalry was on the way out, so there was no longer any point in having a bobble or spike on top of the helmet to deflect the sword blows.
